required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: In Vitro Analysis of Human Urine With the CloudCath Device
clinical_study.official_title: In Vitro Analysis of Human Urine With the CloudCath Device

brief_summary.textblock: This is a multi-center feasibility study to assess the in vitro function of the CloudCath Device that is being developed to derive clinically-relevant information from the optical characteristics of urine.

detailed_description.textblock:
Specimens will be obtained from participants with indwelling catheters in hospital or home settings, who are suspected to be at high risk for urinary tract infection.
To evaluate the performance of the CloudCath Device in repeated measurements over time, multiple specimens may be obtained from the same patients over multiple days or months.
Each sample will be divided into multiple aliquots. One part will be analyzed using the CloudCath Device and reference devices. Another part may be submitted to an independent lab for standard analytical tests.

primary_outcome.time_frame: During the period of time that the patient is catheterized (expected to be up to ~1 week)
primary_outcome.description: A quantitative analysis of the spectral properties of the urine specimen using a proprietary algorithm that results in a quantitative CloudCath Score

arm_group.description: patients who are at high risk for developing a urinary tract infection (UTI).

intervention.description: Urine sample analysis for evidence of urinary tract infection

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- provide a signed informed consent
- patient has an implanted urinary catheter (i.e., Foley, Texas, ureteral)
Exclusion Criteria:
- any condition that the investigator feels may confound the study results or place the participant at risk by participating in the study
- currently taking antibiotics for any reason other than for treatment of urinary tract infection (UTI)
- suprapubic bladder catheter implanted
